1362    def get_importance_step_layer_feature_ablation_abs(
1363        self: str,
1364        layer_name: str,
1365        input: Tensor | tuple[Tensor, ...],
1366        layer_baselines: None | int | float | Tensor | tuple[int | float | Tensor, ...],
1367        target: Tensor | None,
1368        batch_idx: int,
1369        num_batches: int,
1370        if_captum: bool = False,
1371    ) -> Tensor:
1372        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the absolute values of [feature ablation](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-10590-1_53) attribution. We implement this using [Layer Feature Ablation](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#layer-feature-ablation) in Captum.
1373
1374        **Args:**
1375        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
1376        - **input** (`Tensor` | `tuple[Tensor, ...]`): the input batch of the training step.
1377        - **layer_baselines** (`None` | `int` | `float` | `Tensor` | `tuple[int | float | Tensor, ...]`): reference values which replace each layer input / output value when ablated. Please refer to the [Captum documentation](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#captum.attr.LayerFeatureAblation.attribute) for more details.
1378        - **target** (`Tensor` | `None`): the target batch of the training step.
1379        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is an argument of the forward function during training.
1380        - **num_batches** (`int`): the number of batches in the training step. This is an argument of the forward function during training.
1381        - **if_captum** (`bool`): whether to use Captum or not. If `True`, we use Captum to calculate the feature ablation. If `False`, we use our implementation. Default is `False`, because our implementation is much faster.
1382
1383        **Returns:**
1384        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
1385        """
1386        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
1387
1388        if not if_captum:
1389            # 1. Baseline logits (take first element of forward output)
1390            baseline_out, _, _ = self.forward(
1391                input, "train", batch_idx, num_batches, self.task_id
1392            )
1393            if target is not None:
1394                baseline_scores = baseline_out.gather(1, target.view(-1, 1)).squeeze(1)
1395            else:
1396                baseline_scores = baseline_out.sum(dim=1)
1397
1398            # 2. Capture layers output shape
1399            activs = {}
1400            handle = layer.register_forward_hook(
1401                lambda module, inp, out: activs.setdefault("output", out.detach())
1402            )
1403            _, _, _ = self.forward(input, "train", batch_idx, num_batches, self.task_id)
1404            handle.remove()
1405            layer_output = activs["output"]  # shape (B, F, ...)
1406
1407            # 3. Build baseline tensor matching that shape
1408            if layer_baselines is None:
1409                baseline_tensor = torch.zeros_like(layer_output)
1410            elif isinstance(layer_baselines, (int, float)):
1411                baseline_tensor = torch.full_like(layer_output, layer_baselines)
1412            elif isinstance(layer_baselines, Tensor):
1413                if layer_baselines.shape == layer_output.shape:
1414                    baseline_tensor = layer_baselines
1415                elif layer_baselines.shape == layer_output.shape[1:]:
1416                    baseline_tensor = layer_baselines.unsqueeze(0).repeat(
1417                        layer_output.size(0), *([1] * layer_baselines.ndim)
1418                    )
1419                else:
1420                    raise ValueError(...)
1421            else:
1422                raise ValueError(...)
1423
1424            B, F = layer_output.size(0), layer_output.size(1)
1425
1426            # 4. Create a mega-batch replicating the input F times
1427            if isinstance(input, tuple):
1428                mega_inputs = tuple(
1429                    t.unsqueeze(0).repeat(F, *([1] * t.ndim)).view(-1, *t.shape[1:])
1430                    for t in input
1431                )
1432            else:
1433                mega_inputs = (
1434                    input.unsqueeze(0)
1435                    .repeat(F, *([1] * input.ndim))
1436                    .view(-1, *input.shape[1:])
1437                )
1438
1439            # 5. Equally replicate the baseline tensor
1440            mega_baseline = (
1441                baseline_tensor.unsqueeze(0)
1442                .repeat(F, *([1] * baseline_tensor.ndim))
1443                .view(-1, *baseline_tensor.shape[1:])
1444            )
1445
1446            # 6. Precompute vectorized indices
1447            device = layer_output.device
1448            positions = torch.arange(F * B, device=device)  # [0,1,...,F*B-1]
1449            feat_idx = torch.arange(F, device=device).repeat_interleave(
1450                B
1451            )  # [0,0,...,1,1,...,F-1]
1452
1453            # 7. One hook to zero out each channel slice across the mega-batch
1454            def mega_ablate_hook(module, inp, out):
1455                out_mod = out.clone()
1456                # for each sample in mega-batch, zero its corresponding channel
1457                out_mod[positions, feat_idx] = mega_baseline[positions, feat_idx]
1458                return out_mod
1459
1460            h = layer.register_forward_hook(mega_ablate_hook)
1461            out_all, _, _ = self.forward(
1462                mega_inputs, "train", batch_idx, num_batches, self.task_id
1463            )
1464            h.remove()
1465
1466            # 8. Recover scores, reshape [F*B]  [F, B], diff & mean
1467            if target is not None:
1468                tgt_flat = target.unsqueeze(0).repeat(F, 1).view(-1)
1469                scores_all = out_all.gather(1, tgt_flat.view(-1, 1)).squeeze(1)
1470            else:
1471                scores_all = out_all.sum(dim=1)
1472
1473            scores_all = scores_all.view(F, B)
1474            diffs = torch.abs(baseline_scores.unsqueeze(0) - scores_all)
1475            importance_step_layer = diffs.mean(dim=1).detach()  # [F]
1476
1477            return importance_step_layer
1478
1479        else:
1480            # initialize the Layer Feature Ablation object
1481            layer_feature_ablation = LayerFeatureAblation(
1482                forward_func=self.forward, layer=layer
1483            )
1484
1485            # calculate layer attribution of the step
1486            self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(True)
1487            attribution = layer_feature_ablation.attribute(
1488                inputs=input,
1489                layer_baselines=layer_baselines,
1490                # target=target, # disable target to enable perturbations_per_eval
1491                additional_forward_args=("train", batch_idx, num_batches, self.task_id),
1492                perturbations_per_eval=128,  # to accelerate the computation
1493            )
1494            self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(False)
1495
1496            attribution_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
1497                torch.abs(attribution),
1498                dim=[
1499                    i for i in range(attribution.dim()) if i != 1
1500                ],  # average the features over batch samples
1501            )
1502
1503        importance_step_layer = attribution_abs_batch_mean
1504        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
1505
1506        return importance_step_layer
1507
1508    def get_importance_step_layer_lrp_abs(
1509        self: str,
1510        layer_name: str,
1511        input: Tensor | tuple[Tensor, ...],
1512        target: Tensor | None,
1513        batch_idx: int,
1514        num_batches: int,
1515    ) -> Tensor:
1516        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the absolute values of [LRP](https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0130140). We implement this using [Layer LRP](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#layer-lrp) in Captum.
1517
1518        **Args:**
1519        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
1520        - **input** (`Tensor` | `tuple[Tensor, ...]`): the input batch of the training step.
1521        - **target** (`Tensor` | `None`): the target batch of the training step.
1522        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is an argument of the forward function during training.
1523        - **num_batches** (`int`): the number of batches in the training step. This is an argument of the forward function during training.
1524
1525        **Returns:**
1526        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
1527        """
1528        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
1529
1530        # initialize the Layer LRP object
1531        layer_lrp = LayerLRP(model=self, layer=layer)
1532
1533        # set model to evaluation mode to prevent updating the model parameters
1534        self.eval()
1535
1536        self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(True)
1537        # calculate layer attribution of the step
1538        attribution = layer_lrp.attribute(
1539            inputs=input,
1540            target=target,
1541            additional_forward_args=("train", batch_idx, num_batches, self.task_id),
1542        )
1543        self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(False)
1544
1545        attribution_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
1546            torch.abs(attribution),
1547            dim=[
1548                i for i in range(attribution.dim()) if i != 1
1549            ],  # average the features over batch samples
1550        )
1551
1552        importance_step_layer = attribution_abs_batch_mean
1553        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
1554
1555        return importance_step_layer
1556
1557    def get_importance_step_layer_cbp_adaptive_contribution(
1558        self: str,
1559        layer_name: str,
1560        activation: Tensor,
1561    ) -> Tensor:
1562        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the sum of absolute values of layer output weights multiplied by absolute values of activation, then divided by the reciprocal of sum of absolute values of layer input weights. It is equal to the adaptive contribution utility in [CBP](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07711-7).
1563
1564        **Args:**
1565        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
1566        - **activation** (`Tensor`): the activation tensor of the layer. It has the same size of (number of units, ).
1567
1568        **Returns:**
1569        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
1570        """
1571        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
1572
1573        input_weight_abs = torch.abs(layer.weight.data)
1574        input_weight_abs_sum = torch.sum(
1575            input_weight_abs,
1576            dim=[
1577                i for i in range(input_weight_abs.dim()) if i != 0
1578            ],  # sum over the input dimension
1579        )
1580        input_weight_abs_sum_reciprocal = torch.reciprocal(input_weight_abs_sum)
1581
1582        output_weight_abs = torch.abs(self.next_layer(layer_name).weight.data)
1583        output_weight_abs_sum = torch.sum(
1584            output_weight_abs,
1585            dim=[
1586                i for i in range(output_weight_abs.dim()) if i != 1
1587            ],  # sum over the output dimension
1588        )
1589
1590        activation_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
1591            torch.abs(activation),
1592            dim=[
1593                i for i in range(activation.dim()) if i != 1
1594            ],  # average the features over batch samples
1595        )
1596
1597        importance_step_layer = (
1598            output_weight_abs_sum
1599            * activation_abs_batch_mean
1600            * input_weight_abs_sum_reciprocal
1601        )
1602        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
1603
1604        return importance_step_layer
class FGAdaHAT(clarena.cl_algorithms.adahat.AdaHAT): 
  37class FGAdaHAT(AdaHAT):
  38    r"""FG-AdaHAT (Fine-Grained Adaptive Hard Attention to the Task) algorithm.
  39
  40    An architecture-based continual learning approach that improves [AdaHAT (Adaptive Hard Attention to the Task)](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-70352-2_9) by introducing fine-grained neuron-wise importance measures guiding the adaptive adjustment mechanism in AdaHAT.
  41
  42    We implement FG-AdaHAT as a subclass of AdaHAT, as it reuses AdaHAT's summative mask and other components.
  43    """
  44
  45    def __init__(
  46        self,
  47        backbone: HATMaskBackbone,
  48        heads: HeadsTIL,
  49        adjustment_intensity: float,
  50        importance_type: str,
  51        importance_summing_strategy: str,
  52        importance_scheduler_type: str,
  53        neuron_to_weight_importance_aggregation_mode: str,
  54        s_max: float,
  55        clamp_threshold: float,
  56        mask_sparsity_reg_factor: float,
  57        mask_sparsity_reg_mode: str = "original",
  58        base_importance: float = 0.01,
  59        base_mask_sparsity_reg: float = 0.1,
  60        base_linear: float = 10,
  61        filter_by_cumulative_mask: bool = False,
  62        filter_unmasked_importance: bool = True,
  63        step_multiply_training_mask: bool = True,
  64        task_embedding_init_mode: str = "N01",
  65        importance_summing_strategy_linear_step: float | None = None,
  66        importance_summing_strategy_exponential_rate: float | None = None,
  67        importance_summing_strategy_log_base: float | None = None,
  68    ) -> None:
  69        r"""Initialize the FG-AdaHAT algorithm with the network.
  70
  71        **Args:**
  72        - **backbone** (`HATMaskBackbone`): must be a backbone network with the HAT mask mechanism.
  73        - **heads** (`HeadsTIL`): output heads. FG-AdaHAT supports only TIL (Task-Incremental Learning).
  74        - **adjustment_intensity** (`float`): hyperparameter, controls the overall intensity of gradient adjustment (the $\alpha$ in the paper).
  75        - **importance_type** (`str`): the type of neuron-wise importance, must be one of:
  76            1. 'input_weight_abs_sum': sum of absolute input weights;
  77            2. 'output_weight_abs_sum': sum of absolute output weights;
  78            3. 'input_weight_gradient_abs_sum': sum of absolute gradients of the input weights (Input Gradients (IG) in the paper);
  79            4. 'output_weight_gradient_abs_sum': sum of absolute gradients of the output weights (Output Gradients (OG) in the paper);
  80            5. 'activation_abs': absolute activation;
  81            6. 'input_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs': sum of absolute input weights multiplied by absolute activation (Input Contribution Utility (ICU) in the paper);
  82            7. 'output_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs': sum of absolute output weights multiplied by absolute activation (Contribution Utility (CU) in the paper);
  83            8. 'gradient_x_activation_abs': absolute gradient (the saliency) multiplied by activation;
  84            9. 'input_weight_gradient_square_sum': sum of squared gradients of the input weights;
  85            10. 'output_weight_gradient_square_sum': sum of squared gradients of the output weights;
  86            11. 'input_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs': sum of squared gradients of the input weights multiplied by absolute activation (Activation Fisher Information (AFI) in the paper);
  87            12. 'output_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs': sum of squared gradients of the output weights multiplied by absolute activation;
  88            13. 'conductance_abs': absolute layer conductance;
  89            14. 'internal_influence_abs': absolute internal influence (Internal Influence (II) in the paper);
  90            15. 'gradcam_abs': absolute Grad-CAM;
  91            16. 'deeplift_abs': absolute DeepLIFT (DeepLIFT (DL) in the paper);
  92            17. 'deepliftshap_abs': absolute DeepLIFT-SHAP;
  93            18. 'gradientshap_abs': absolute Gradient-SHAP (Gradient SHAP (GS) in the paper);
  94            19. 'integrated_gradients_abs': absolute Integrated Gradients;
  95            20. 'feature_ablation_abs': absolute Feature Ablation (Feature Ablation (FA) in the paper);
  96            21. 'lrp_abs': absolute Layer-wise Relevance Propagation (LRP);
  97            22. 'cbp_adaptation': the adaptation function in [Continual Backpropagation (CBP)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07711-7);
  98            23. 'cbp_adaptive_contribution': the adaptive contribution function in [Continual Backpropagation (CBP)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07711-7);
  99        - **importance_summing_strategy** (`str`): the strategy to sum neuron-wise importance for previous tasks, must be one of:
 100            1. 'add_latest': add the latest neuron-wise importance to the summative importance;
 101            2. 'add_all': add all previous neuron-wise importance (including the latest) to the summative importance;
 102            3. 'add_average': add the average of all previous neuron-wise importance (including the latest) to the summative importance;
 103            4. 'linear_decrease': weigh the previous neuron-wise importance by a linear factor that decreases with the task ID;
 104            5. 'quadratic_decrease': weigh the previous neuron-wise importance that decreases quadratically with the task ID;
 105            6. 'cubic_decrease': weigh the previous neuron-wise importance that decreases cubically with the task ID;
 106            7. 'exponential_decrease': weigh the previous neuron-wise importance by an exponential factor that decreases with the task ID;
 107            8. 'log_decrease': weigh the previous neuron-wise importance by a logarithmic factor that decreases with the task ID;
 108            9. 'factorial_decrease': weigh the previous neuron-wise importance that decreases factorially with the task ID;
 109        - **importance_scheduler_type** (`str`): the scheduler for importance, i.e., the factor $c^t$ multiplied to parameter importance. Must be one of:
 110            1. 'linear_sparsity_reg': $c^t = (t+b_L) \cdot [R(M^t, M^{<t}) + b_R]$, where $R(M^t, M^{<t})$ is the mask sparsity regularization betwwen the current task and previous tasks, $b_L$ is the base linear factor (see argument `base_linear`), and $b_R$ is the base mask sparsity regularization factor (see argument `base_mask_sparsity_reg`);
 111            2. 'sparsity_reg': $c^t = [R(M^t, M^{<t}) + b_R]$;
 112            3. 'summative_mask_sparsity_reg': $c^t_{l,ij} = \left(\min \left(m^{<t, \text{sum}}_{l,i}, m^{<t, \text{sum}}_{l-1,j}\right)+b_L\right) \cdot [R(M^t, M^{<t}) + b_R]$.
 113        - **neuron_to_weight_importance_aggregation_mode** (`str`): aggregation mode from neuron-wise to weight-wise importance ($\text{Agg}(\cdot)$ in the paper), must be one of:
 114            1. 'min': take the minimum of neuron-wise importance for each weight;
 115            2. 'max': take the maximum of neuron-wise importance for each weight;
 116            3. 'mean': take the mean of neuron-wise importance for each weight.
 117        - **s_max** (`float`): hyperparameter, the maximum scaling factor in the gate function. See Sec. 2.4 "Hard Attention Training" in the [HAT paper](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a).
 118        - **clamp_threshold** (`float`): the threshold for task embedding gradient compensation. See Sec. 2.5 "Embedding Gradient Compensation" in the [HAT paper](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a).
 119        - **mask_sparsity_reg_factor** (`float`): hyperparameter, the regularization factor for mask sparsity.
 120        - **mask_sparsity_reg_mode** (`str`): the mode of mask sparsity regularization, must be one of:
 121            1. 'original' (default): the original mask sparsity regularization in the [HAT paper](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a).
 122            2. 'cross': the cross version of mask sparsity regularization.
 123        - **base_importance** (`float`): base value added to importance ($b_I$ in the paper). Default: 0.01.
 124        - **base_mask_sparsity_reg** (`float`): base value added to mask sparsity regularization factor in the importance scheduler ($b_R$ in the paper). Default: 0.1.
 125        - **base_linear** (`float`): base value added to the linear factor in the importance scheduler ($b_L$ in the paper). Default: 10.
 126        - **filter_by_cumulative_mask** (`bool`): whether to multiply the cumulative mask to the importance when calculating adjustment rate. Default: False.
 127        - **filter_unmasked_importance** (`bool`): whether to filter unmasked importance values (set to 0) at the end of task training. Default: False.
 128        - **step_multiply_training_mask** (`bool`): whether to multiply the training mask to the importance at each training step. Default: True.
 129        - **task_embedding_init_mode** (`str`): the initialization mode for task embeddings, must be one of:
 130            1. 'N01' (default): standard normal distribution $N(0, 1)$.
 131            2. 'U-11': uniform distribution $U(-1, 1)$.
 132            3. 'U01': uniform distribution $U(0, 1)$.
 133            4. 'U-10': uniform distribution $U(-1, 0)$.
 134            5. 'last': inherit the task embedding from the last task.
 135        - **importance_summing_strategy_linear_step** (`float` | `None`): linear step for the importance summing strategy (used when `importance_summing_strategy` is 'linear_decrease'). Must be > 0.
 136        - **importance_summing_strategy_exponential_rate** (`float` | `None`): exponential rate for the importance summing strategy (used when `importance_summing_strategy` is 'exponential_decrease'). Must be > 1.
 137        - **importance_summing_strategy_log_base** (`float` | `None`): base for the logarithm in the importance summing strategy (used when `importance_summing_strategy` is 'log_decrease'). Must be > 1.
 138        """
 139        super().__init__(
 140            backbone=backbone,
 141            heads=heads,
 142            adjustment_mode=None,  # use the own adjustment mechanism of FG-AdaHAT
 143            adjustment_intensity=adjustment_intensity,
 144            s_max=s_max,
 145            clamp_threshold=clamp_threshold,
 146            mask_sparsity_reg_factor=mask_sparsity_reg_factor,
 147            mask_sparsity_reg_mode=mask_sparsity_reg_mode,
 148            task_embedding_init_mode=task_embedding_init_mode,
 149            epsilon=base_mask_sparsity_reg,  # the epsilon is now the base mask sparsity regularization factor
 150        )
 151
 152        self.importance_type: str | None = importance_type
 153        r"""The type of the neuron-wise importance added to AdaHAT importance."""
 154
 155        self.importance_scheduler_type: str = importance_scheduler_type
 156        r"""Store the type of the importance scheduler."""
 157        self.neuron_to_weight_importance_aggregation_mode: str = (
 158            neuron_to_weight_importance_aggregation_mode
 159        )
 160        r"""The mode of aggregation from neuron-wise to weight-wise importance. """
 161        self.filter_by_cumulative_mask: bool = filter_by_cumulative_mask
 162        r"""The flag to filter importance by the cumulative mask when calculating the adjustment rate."""
 163        self.filter_unmasked_importance: bool = filter_unmasked_importance
 164        r"""The flag to filter unmasked importance values (set them to 0) at the end of task training."""
 165        self.step_multiply_training_mask: bool = step_multiply_training_mask
 166        r"""The flag to multiply the training mask to the importance at each training step."""
 167
 168        # importance summing strategy
 169        self.importance_summing_strategy: str = importance_summing_strategy
 170        r"""The strategy to sum the neuron-wise importance for previous tasks."""
 171        if importance_summing_strategy_linear_step is not None:
 172            self.importance_summing_strategy_linear_step: float = (
 173                importance_summing_strategy_linear_step
 174            )
 175            r"""The linear step for the importance summing strategy (only when `importance_summing_strategy` is 'linear_decrease')."""
 176        if importance_summing_strategy_exponential_rate is not None:
 177            self.importance_summing_strategy_exponential_rate: float = (
 178                importance_summing_strategy_exponential_rate
 179            )
 180            r"""The exponential rate for the importance summing strategy (only when `importance_summing_strategy` is 'exponential_decrease'). """
 181        if importance_summing_strategy_log_base is not None:
 182            self.importance_summing_strategy_log_base: float = (
 183                importance_summing_strategy_log_base
 184            )
 185            r"""The base for the logarithm in the importance summing strategy (only when `importance_summing_strategy` is 'log_decrease'). """
 186
 187        # base values
 188        self.base_importance: float = base_importance
 189        r"""The base value added to the importance to avoid zero. """
 190        self.base_mask_sparsity_reg: float = base_mask_sparsity_reg
 191        r"""The base value added to the mask sparsity regularization to avoid zero. """
 192        self.base_linear: float = base_linear
 193        r"""The base value added to the linear layer to avoid zero. """
 194
 195        self.importances: dict[int, dict[str, Tensor]] = {}
 196        r"""The min-max scaled ($[0, 1]$) neuron-wise importance of units. It is $I^{\tau}_{l}$ in the paper. Keys are task IDs and values are the corresponding importance tensors. Each importance tensor is a dict where keys are layer names and values are the importance tensor for the layer. The utility tensor is the same size as the feature tensor with size (number of units, ). """
 197        self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks: dict[str, Tensor] = {}
 198        r"""The summative neuron-wise importance values of units for previous tasks before the current task `self.task_id`. See $I^{<t}_{l}$ in the paper. Keys are layer names and values are the summative importance tensor for the layer. The summative importance tensor has the same size as the feature tensor with size (number of units, ). """
 199
 200        self.num_steps_t: int
 201        r"""Store the number of training steps for the current task `self.task_id`."""
 202        # set manual optimization
 203        self.automatic_optimization = False
 204
 205        FGAdaHAT.sanity_check(self)
 206
 207    def sanity_check(self) -> None:
 208        r"""Check the sanity of the arguments."""
 209
 210        # check importance type
 211        if self.importance_type not in [
 212            "input_weight_abs_sum",
 213            "output_weight_abs_sum",
 214            "input_weight_gradient_abs_sum",
 215            "output_weight_gradient_abs_sum",
 216            "activation_abs",
 217            "input_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs",
 218            "output_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs",
 219            "gradient_x_activation_abs",
 220            "input_weight_gradient_square_sum",
 221            "output_weight_gradient_square_sum",
 222            "input_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs",
 223            "output_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs",
 224            "conductance_abs",
 225            "internal_influence_abs",
 226            "gradcam_abs",
 227            "deeplift_abs",
 228            "deepliftshap_abs",
 229            "gradientshap_abs",
 230            "integrated_gradients_abs",
 231            "feature_ablation_abs",
 232            "lrp_abs",
 233            "cbp_adaptation",
 234            "cbp_adaptive_contribution",
 235        ]:
 236            raise ValueError(
 237                f"importance_type must be one of the predefined types, but got {self.importance_type}"
 238            )
 239
 240        # check importance summing strategy
 241        if self.importance_summing_strategy not in [
 242            "add_latest",
 243            "add_all",
 244            "add_average",
 245            "linear_decrease",
 246            "quadratic_decrease",
 247            "cubic_decrease",
 248            "exponential_decrease",
 249            "log_decrease",
 250            "factorial_decrease",
 251        ]:
 252            raise ValueError(
 253                f"importance_summing_strategy must be one of the predefined strategies, but got {self.importance_summing_strategy}"
 254            )
 255
 256        # check importance scheduler type
 257        if self.importance_scheduler_type not in [
 258            "linear_sparsity_reg",
 259            "sparsity_reg",
 260            "summative_mask_sparsity_reg",
 261        ]:
 262            raise ValueError(
 263                f"importance_scheduler_type must be one of the predefined types, but got {self.importance_scheduler_type}"
 264            )
 265
 266        # check neuron to weight importance aggregation mode
 267        if self.neuron_to_weight_importance_aggregation_mode not in [
 268            "min",
 269            "max",
 270            "mean",
 271        ]:
 272            raise ValueError(
 273                f"neuron_to_weight_importance_aggregation_mode must be one of the predefined modes, but got {self.neuron_to_weight_importance_aggregation_mode}"
 274            )
 275
 276        # check base values
 277        if self.base_importance < 0:
 278            raise ValueError(
 279                f"base_importance must be >= 0, but got {self.base_importance}"
 280            )
 281        if self.base_mask_sparsity_reg <= 0:
 282            raise ValueError(
 283                f"base_mask_sparsity_reg must be > 0, but got {self.base_mask_sparsity_reg}"
 284            )
 285        if self.base_linear <= 0:
 286            raise ValueError(f"base_linear must be > 0, but got {self.base_linear}")
 287
 288    def on_train_start(self) -> None:
 289        r"""Initialize neuron importance accumulation variable for each layer as zeros, in addition to AdaHAT's summative mask initialization."""
 290        super().on_train_start()
 291
 292        self.importances[self.task_id] = (
 293            {}
 294        )  # initialize the importance for the current task
 295
 296        # initialize the neuron importance at the beginning of each task. This should not be called in `__init__()` method because `self.device` is not available at that time.
 297        for layer_name in self.backbone.weighted_layer_names:
 298            layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(
 299                layer_name
 300            )  # get the layer by its name
 301            num_units = layer.weight.shape[0]
 302
 303            # initialize the accumulated importance at the beginning of each task
 304            self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name] = torch.zeros(num_units).to(
 305                self.device
 306            )
 307
 308            # reset the number of steps counter for the current task
 309            self.num_steps_t = 0
 310
 311            # initialize the summative neuron-wise importance at the beginning of the first task
 312            if self.task_id == 1:
 313                self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks[layer_name] = torch.zeros(
 314                    num_units
 315                ).to(
 316                    self.device
 317                )  # the summative neuron-wise importance for previous tasks $I^{<t}_{l}$ is initialized as zeros mask when $t=1$
 318
 319    def clip_grad_by_adjustment(
 320        self,
 321        network_sparsity: dict[str, Tensor],
 322    ) -> tuple[dict[str, Tensor], dict[str, Tensor], Tensor]:
 323        r"""Clip the gradients by the adjustment rate. See Eq. (1) in the paper.
 324
 325        Note that because the task embedding fully covers every layer in the backbone network, no parameters are left out of this system. This applies not only to parameters between layers with task embeddings, but also to those before the first layer. We design it separately in the code.
 326
 327        Network capacity is measured alongside this method. Network capacity is defined as the average adjustment rate over all parameters. See Sec. 4.1 in the [AdaHAT paper](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-70352-2_9).
 328
 329        **Args:**
 330        - **network_sparsity** (`dict[str, Tensor]`): the network sparsity (i.e., mask sparsity loss of each layer) for the current task. Keys are layer names and values are the network sparsity values. It is used to calculate the adjustment rate for gradients. In FG-AdaHAT, it is used to construct the importance scheduler.
 331
 332        **Returns:**
 333        - **adjustment_rate_weight** (`dict[str, Tensor]`): the adjustment rate for weights. Keys (`str`) are layer names and values (`Tensor`) are the adjustment rate tensors.
 334        - **adjustment_rate_bias** (`dict[str, Tensor]`): the adjustment rate for biases. Keys (`str`) are layer names and values (`Tensor`) are the adjustment rate tensors.
 335        - **capacity** (`Tensor`): the calculated network capacity.
 336        """
 337
 338        # initialize network capacity metric
 339        capacity = HATNetworkCapacityMetric().to(self.device)
 340        adjustment_rate_weight = {}
 341        adjustment_rate_bias = {}
 342
 343        # calculate the adjustment rate for gradients of the parameters, both weights and biases (if they exist). See Eq. (2) in the paper
 344        for layer_name in self.backbone.weighted_layer_names:
 345
 346            layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(
 347                layer_name
 348            )  # get the layer by its name
 349
 350            # placeholder for the adjustment rate to avoid the error of using it before assignment
 351            adjustment_rate_weight_layer = 1
 352            adjustment_rate_bias_layer = 1
 353
 354            # aggregate the neuron-wise importance to weight-wise importance. Note that the neuron-wise importance has already been min-max scaled to $[0, 1]$ in the `on_train_batch_end()` method, added the base value, and filtered by the mask
 355            weight_importance, bias_importance = (
 356                self.backbone.get_layer_measure_parameter_wise(
 357                    unit_wise_measure=self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks,
 358                    layer_name=layer_name,
 359                    aggregation_mode=self.neuron_to_weight_importance_aggregation_mode,
 360                )
 361            )
 362
 363            weight_mask, bias_mask = self.backbone.get_layer_measure_parameter_wise(
 364                unit_wise_measure=self.cumulative_mask_for_previous_tasks,
 365                layer_name=layer_name,
 366                aggregation_mode="min",
 367            )
 368
 369            # filter the weight importance by the cumulative mask
 370            if self.filter_by_cumulative_mask:
 371                weight_importance = weight_importance * weight_mask
 372                bias_importance = bias_importance * bias_mask
 373
 374            network_sparsity_layer = network_sparsity[layer_name]
 375
 376            # calculate importance scheduler (the factor of importance). See Eq. (3) in the paper
 377            factor = network_sparsity_layer + self.base_mask_sparsity_reg
 378            if self.importance_scheduler_type == "linear_sparsity_reg":
 379                factor = factor * (self.task_id + self.base_linear)
 380            elif self.importance_scheduler_type == "sparsity_reg":
 381                pass
 382            elif self.importance_scheduler_type == "summative_mask_sparsity_reg":
 383                factor = factor * (
 384                    self.summative_mask_for_previous_tasks + self.base_linear
 385                )
 386
 387            # calculate the adjustment rate
 388            adjustment_rate_weight_layer = torch.div(
 389                self.adjustment_intensity,
 390                (factor * weight_importance + self.adjustment_intensity),
 391            )
 392
 393            adjustment_rate_bias_layer = torch.div(
 394                self.adjustment_intensity,
 395                (factor * bias_importance + self.adjustment_intensity),
 396            )
 397
 398            # apply the adjustment rate to the gradients
 399            layer.weight.grad.data *= adjustment_rate_weight_layer
 400            if layer.bias is not None:
 401                layer.bias.grad.data *= adjustment_rate_bias_layer
 402
 403            # store the adjustment rate for logging
 404            adjustment_rate_weight[layer_name] = adjustment_rate_weight_layer
 405            if layer.bias is not None:
 406                adjustment_rate_bias[layer_name] = adjustment_rate_bias_layer
 407
 408            # update network capacity metric
 409            capacity.update(adjustment_rate_weight_layer, adjustment_rate_bias_layer)
 410
 411        return adjustment_rate_weight, adjustment_rate_bias, capacity.compute()
 412
 413    def on_train_batch_end(
 414        self, outputs: dict[str, Any], batch: Any, batch_idx: int
 415    ) -> None:
 416        r"""Calculate the step-wise importance, update the accumulated importance and number of steps counter after each training step.
 417
 418        **Args:**
 419        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): outputs of the training step (returns of `training_step()` in `CLAlgorithm`).
 420        - **batch** (`Any`): training data batch.
 421        - **batch_idx** (`int`): index of the current batch (for mask figure file name).
 422        """
 423
 424        # get potential useful information from training batch
 425        activations = outputs["activations"]
 426        input = outputs["input"]
 427        target = outputs["target"]
 428        mask = outputs["mask"]
 429        num_batches = self.trainer.num_training_batches
 430
 431        for layer_name in self.backbone.weighted_layer_names:
 432            # layer-wise operation
 433
 434            activation = activations[layer_name]
 435
 436            # calculate neuron-wise importance of the training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper.
 437            if self.importance_type == "input_weight_abs_sum":
 438                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_abs_sum(
 439                    layer_name=layer_name,
 440                    if_output_weight=False,
 441                    reciprocal=False,
 442                )
 443            elif self.importance_type == "output_weight_abs_sum":
 444                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_abs_sum(
 445                    layer_name=layer_name,
 446                    if_output_weight=True,
 447                    reciprocal=False,
 448                )
 449            elif self.importance_type == "input_weight_gradient_abs_sum":
 450                importance_step = (
 451                    self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_abs_sum(
 452                        layer_name=layer_name, if_output_weight=False
 453                    )
 454                )
 455            elif self.importance_type == "output_weight_gradient_abs_sum":
 456                importance_step = (
 457                    self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_abs_sum(
 458                        layer_name=layer_name, if_output_weight=True
 459                    )
 460                )
 461            elif self.importance_type == "activation_abs":
 462                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_activation_abs(
 463                    activation=activation
 464                )
 465            elif self.importance_type == "input_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs":
 466                importance_step = (
 467                    self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs(
 468                        layer_name=layer_name,
 469                        activation=activation,
 470                        if_output_weight=False,
 471                    )
 472                )
 473            elif self.importance_type == "output_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs":
 474                importance_step = (
 475                    self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs(
 476                        layer_name=layer_name,
 477                        activation=activation,
 478                        if_output_weight=True,
 479                    )
 480                )
 481            elif self.importance_type == "gradient_x_activation_abs":
 482                importance_step = (
 483                    self.get_importance_step_layer_gradient_x_activation_abs(
 484                        layer_name=layer_name,
 485                        input=input,
 486                        target=target,
 487                        batch_idx=batch_idx,
 488                        num_batches=num_batches,
 489                    )
 490                )
 491            elif self.importance_type == "input_weight_gradient_square_sum":
 492                importance_step = (
 493                    self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_square_sum(
 494                        layer_name=layer_name,
 495                        activation=activation,
 496                        if_output_weight=False,
 497                    )
 498                )
 499            elif self.importance_type == "output_weight_gradient_square_sum":
 500                importance_step = (
 501                    self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_square_sum(
 502                        layer_name=layer_name,
 503                        activation=activation,
 504                        if_output_weight=True,
 505                    )
 506                )
 507            elif (
 508                self.importance_type
 509                == "input_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs"
 510            ):
 511                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs(
 512                    layer_name=layer_name,
 513                    activation=activation,
 514                    if_output_weight=False,
 515                )
 516            elif (
 517                self.importance_type
 518                == "output_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs"
 519            ):
 520                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs(
 521                    layer_name=layer_name,
 522                    activation=activation,
 523                    if_output_weight=True,
 524                )
 525            elif self.importance_type == "conductance_abs":
 526                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_conductance_abs(
 527                    layer_name=layer_name,
 528                    input=input,
 529                    baselines=None,
 530                    target=target,
 531                    batch_idx=batch_idx,
 532                    num_batches=num_batches,
 533                )
 534            elif self.importance_type == "internal_influence_abs":
 535                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_internal_influence_abs(
 536                    layer_name=layer_name,
 537                    input=input,
 538                    baselines=None,
 539                    target=target,
 540                    batch_idx=batch_idx,
 541                    num_batches=num_batches,
 542                )
 543            elif self.importance_type == "gradcam_abs":
 544                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_gradcam_abs(
 545                    layer_name=layer_name,
 546                    input=input,
 547                    target=target,
 548                    batch_idx=batch_idx,
 549                    num_batches=num_batches,
 550                )
 551            elif self.importance_type == "deeplift_abs":
 552                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_deeplift_abs(
 553                    layer_name=layer_name,
 554                    input=input,
 555                    baselines=None,
 556                    target=target,
 557                    batch_idx=batch_idx,
 558                    num_batches=num_batches,
 559                )
 560            elif self.importance_type == "deepliftshap_abs":
 561                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_deepliftshap_abs(
 562                    layer_name=layer_name,
 563                    input=input,
 564                    baselines=None,
 565                    target=target,
 566                    batch_idx=batch_idx,
 567                    num_batches=num_batches,
 568                )
 569            elif self.importance_type == "gradientshap_abs":
 570                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_gradientshap_abs(
 571                    layer_name=layer_name,
 572                    input=input,
 573                    baselines=None,
 574                    target=target,
 575                    batch_idx=batch_idx,
 576                    num_batches=num_batches,
 577                )
 578            elif self.importance_type == "integrated_gradients_abs":
 579                importance_step = (
 580                    self.get_importance_step_layer_integrated_gradients_abs(
 581                        layer_name=layer_name,
 582                        input=input,
 583                        baselines=None,
 584                        target=target,
 585                        batch_idx=batch_idx,
 586                        num_batches=num_batches,
 587                    )
 588                )
 589            elif self.importance_type == "feature_ablation_abs":
 590                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_feature_ablation_abs(
 591                    layer_name=layer_name,
 592                    input=input,
 593                    layer_baselines=None,
 594                    target=target,
 595                    batch_idx=batch_idx,
 596                    num_batches=num_batches,
 597                )
 598            elif self.importance_type == "lrp_abs":
 599                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_lrp_abs(
 600                    layer_name=layer_name,
 601                    input=input,
 602                    target=target,
 603                    batch_idx=batch_idx,
 604                    num_batches=num_batches,
 605                )
 606            elif self.importance_type == "cbp_adaptation":
 607                importance_step = self.get_importance_step_layer_weight_abs_sum(
 608                    layer_name=layer_name,
 609                    if_output_weight=False,
 610                    reciprocal=True,
 611                )
 612            elif self.importance_type == "cbp_adaptive_contribution":
 613                importance_step = (
 614                    self.get_importance_step_layer_cbp_adaptive_contribution(
 615                        layer_name=layer_name,
 616                        activation=activation,
 617                    )
 618                )
 619
 620            importance_step = min_max_normalize(
 621                importance_step
 622            )  # min-max scaling the utility to $[0, 1]$. See Eq. (5) in the paper
 623
 624            # multiply the importance by the training mask. See Eq. (6) in the paper
 625            if self.step_multiply_training_mask:
 626                importance_step = importance_step * mask[layer_name]
 627
 628            # update accumulated importance
 629            self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name] = (
 630                self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name] + importance_step
 631            )
 632
 633        # update number of steps counter
 634        self.num_steps_t += 1
 635
 636    def on_train_end(self) -> None:
 637        r"""Additionally calculate neuron-wise importance for previous tasks at the end of training each task."""
 638        super().on_train_end()  # store the mask and update cumulative and summative masks
 639
 640        for layer_name in self.backbone.weighted_layer_names:
 641
 642            # average the neuron-wise step importance. See Eq. (4) in the paper
 643            self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name] = (
 644                self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name]
 645            ) / self.num_steps_t
 646
 647            # add the base importance. See Eq. (6) in the paper
 648            self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name] = (
 649                self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name] + self.base_importance
 650            )
 651
 652            # filter unmasked importance
 653            if self.filter_unmasked_importance:
 654                self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name] = (
 655                    self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name]
 656                    * self.backbone.masks[f"{self.task_id}"][layer_name]
 657                )
 658
 659            # calculate the summative neuron-wise importance for previous tasks. See Eq. (4) in the paper
 660            if self.importance_summing_strategy == "add_latest":
 661                self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks[
 662                    layer_name
 663                ] += self.importances[self.task_id][layer_name]
 664
 665            elif self.importance_summing_strategy == "add_all":
 666                for t in range(1, self.task_id + 1):
 667                    self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks[
 668                        layer_name
 669                    ] += self.importances[t][layer_name]
 670
 671            elif self.importance_summing_strategy == "add_average":
 672                for t in range(1, self.task_id + 1):
 673                    self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks[layer_name] += (
 674                        self.importances[t][layer_name] / self.task_id
 675                    )
 676            else:
 677                self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks[
 678                    layer_name
 679                ] = torch.zeros_like(
 680                    self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks[layer_name]
 681                ).to(
 682                    self.device
 683                )  # starting adding from 0
 684
 685                if self.importance_summing_strategy == "linear_decrease":
 686                    s = self.importance_summing_strategy_linear_step
 687                    for t in range(1, self.task_id + 1):
 688                        w_t = s * (self.task_id - t) + 1
 689
 690                elif self.importance_summing_strategy == "quadratic_decrease":
 691                    for t in range(1, self.task_id + 1):
 692                        w_t = (self.task_id - t + 1) ** 2
 693                elif self.importance_summing_strategy == "cubic_decrease":
 694                    for t in range(1, self.task_id + 1):
 695                        w_t = (self.task_id - t + 1) ** 3
 696                elif self.importance_summing_strategy == "exponential_decrease":
 697                    for t in range(1, self.task_id + 1):
 698                        r = self.importance_summing_strategy_exponential_rate
 699
 700                        w_t = r ** (self.task_id - t + 1)
 701                elif self.importance_summing_strategy == "log_decrease":
 702                    a = self.importance_summing_strategy_log_base
 703                    for t in range(1, self.task_id + 1):
 704                        w_t = math.log(self.task_id - t, a) + 1
 705                elif self.importance_summing_strategy == "factorial_decrease":
 706                    for t in range(1, self.task_id + 1):
 707                        w_t = math.factorial(self.task_id - t + 1)
 708                else:
 709                    raise ValueError
 710                self.summative_importance_for_previous_tasks[layer_name] += (
 711                    self.importances[t][layer_name] * w_t
 712                )
 713
 714    def get_importance_step_layer_weight_abs_sum(
 715        self: str,
 716        layer_name: str,
 717        if_output_weight: bool,
 718        reciprocal: bool,
 719    ) -> Tensor:
 720        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the sum of absolute values of layer input or output weights.
 721
 722        **Args:**
 723        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
 724        - **if_output_weight** (`bool`): whether to use the output weights or input weights.
 725        - **reciprocal** (`bool`): whether to take reciprocal.
 726
 727        **Returns:**
 728        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
 729        """
 730        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
 731
 732        if not if_output_weight:
 733            weight_abs = torch.abs(layer.weight.data)
 734            weight_abs_sum = torch.sum(
 735                weight_abs,
 736                dim=[
 737                    i for i in range(weight_abs.dim()) if i != 0
 738                ],  # sum over the input dimension
 739            )
 740        else:
 741            weight_abs = torch.abs(self.next_layer(layer_name).weight.data)
 742            weight_abs_sum = torch.sum(
 743                weight_abs,
 744                dim=[
 745                    i for i in range(weight_abs.dim()) if i != 1
 746                ],  # sum over the output dimension
 747            )
 748
 749        if reciprocal:
 750            weight_abs_sum_reciprocal = torch.reciprocal(weight_abs_sum)
 751            importance_step_layer = weight_abs_sum_reciprocal
 752        else:
 753            importance_step_layer = weight_abs_sum
 754        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
 755
 756        return importance_step_layer
 757
 758    def get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_abs_sum(
 759        self: str,
 760        layer_name: str,
 761        if_output_weight: bool,
 762    ) -> Tensor:
 763        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the sum of absolute values of gradients of the layer input or output weights.
 764
 765        **Args:**
 766        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
 767        - **if_output_weight** (`bool`): whether to use the output weights or input weights.
 768
 769        **Returns:**
 770        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
 771        """
 772        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
 773
 774        if not if_output_weight:
 775            gradient_abs = torch.abs(layer.weight.grad.data)
 776            gradient_abs_sum = torch.sum(
 777                gradient_abs,
 778                dim=[
 779                    i for i in range(gradient_abs.dim()) if i != 0
 780                ],  # sum over the input dimension
 781            )
 782        else:
 783            gradient_abs = torch.abs(self.next_layer(layer_name).weight.grad.data)
 784            gradient_abs_sum = torch.sum(
 785                gradient_abs,
 786                dim=[
 787                    i for i in range(gradient_abs.dim()) if i != 1
 788                ],  # sum over the output dimension
 789            )
 790
 791        importance_step_layer = gradient_abs_sum
 792        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
 793
 794        return importance_step_layer
 795
 796    def get_importance_step_layer_activation_abs(
 797        self: str,
 798        activation: Tensor,
 799    ) -> Tensor:
 800        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the absolute value of activation of the layer. This is our own implementation of [Layer Activation](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#layer-activation) in Captum.
 801
 802        **Args:**
 803        - **activation** (`Tensor`): the activation tensor of the layer. It has the same size of (number of units, ).
 804
 805        **Returns:**
 806        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
 807        """
 808        activation_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
 809            torch.abs(activation),
 810            dim=[
 811                i for i in range(activation.dim()) if i != 1
 812            ],  # average the features over batch samples
 813        )
 814        importance_step_layer = activation_abs_batch_mean
 815        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
 816
 817        return importance_step_layer
 818
 819    def get_importance_step_layer_weight_abs_sum_x_activation_abs(
 820        self: str,
 821        layer_name: str,
 822        activation: Tensor,
 823        if_output_weight: bool,
 824    ) -> Tensor:
 825        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the sum of absolute values of layer input / output weights multiplied by absolute values of activation. The input weights version is equal to the contribution utility in [CBP](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07711-7).
 826
 827        **Args:**
 828        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
 829        - **activation** (`Tensor`): the activation tensor of the layer. It has the same size of (number of units, ).
 830        - **if_output_weight** (`bool`): whether to use the output weights or input weights.
 831
 832        **Returns:**
 833        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
 834        """
 835        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
 836
 837        if not if_output_weight:
 838            weight_abs = torch.abs(layer.weight.data)
 839            weight_abs_sum = torch.sum(
 840                weight_abs,
 841                dim=[
 842                    i for i in range(weight_abs.dim()) if i != 0
 843                ],  # sum over the input dimension
 844            )
 845        else:
 846            weight_abs = torch.abs(self.next_layer(layer_name).weight.data)
 847            weight_abs_sum = torch.sum(
 848                weight_abs,
 849                dim=[
 850                    i for i in range(weight_abs.dim()) if i != 1
 851                ],  # sum over the output dimension
 852            )
 853
 854        activation_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
 855            torch.abs(activation),
 856            dim=[
 857                i for i in range(activation.dim()) if i != 1
 858            ],  # average the features over batch samples
 859        )
 860
 861        importance_step_layer = weight_abs_sum * activation_abs_batch_mean
 862        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
 863
 864        return importance_step_layer
 865
 866    def get_importance_step_layer_gradient_x_activation_abs(
 867        self: str,
 868        layer_name: str,
 869        input: Tensor | tuple[Tensor, ...],
 870        target: Tensor | None,
 871        batch_idx: int,
 872        num_batches: int,
 873    ) -> Tensor:
 874        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the absolute values of the gradient of layer activation multiplied by the activation. We implement this using [Layer Gradient X Activation](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#layer-gradient-x-activation) in Captum.
 875
 876        **Args:**
 877        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
 878        - **input** (`Tensor` | `tuple[Tensor, ...]`): the input batch of the training step.
 879        - **target** (`Tensor` | `None`): the target batch of the training step.
 880        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is an argument of the forward function during training.
 881        - **num_batches** (`int`): the number of batches in the training step. This is an argument of the forward function during training.
 882
 883        **Returns:**
 884        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
 885        """
 886        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
 887
 888        input = input.requires_grad_()
 889
 890        # initialize the Layer Gradient X Activation object
 891        layer_gradient_x_activation = LayerGradientXActivation(
 892            forward_func=self.forward, layer=layer
 893        )
 894
 895        self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(True)
 896        # calculate layer attribution of the step
 897        attribution = layer_gradient_x_activation.attribute(
 898            inputs=input,
 899            target=target,
 900            additional_forward_args=("train", batch_idx, num_batches, self.task_id),
 901        )
 902        self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(False)
 903
 904        attribution_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
 905            torch.abs(attribution),
 906            dim=[
 907                i for i in range(attribution.dim()) if i != 1
 908            ],  # average the features over batch samples
 909        )
 910
 911        importance_step_layer = attribution_abs_batch_mean
 912        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
 913
 914        return importance_step_layer
 915
 916    def get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_square_sum(
 917        self: str,
 918        layer_name: str,
 919        activation: Tensor,
 920        if_output_weight: bool,
 921    ) -> Tensor:
 922        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the sum of layer weight gradient squares. The weight gradient square is equal to fisher information in [EWC](https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.1611835114).
 923
 924        **Args:**
 925        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
 926        - **activation** (`Tensor`): the activation tensor of the layer. It has the same size of (number of units, ).
 927        - **if_output_weight** (`bool`): whether to use the output weights or input weights.
 928
 929        **Returns:**
 930        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
 931        """
 932        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
 933
 934        if not if_output_weight:
 935            gradient_square = layer.weight.grad.data**2
 936            gradient_square_sum = torch.sum(
 937                gradient_square,
 938                dim=[
 939                    i for i in range(gradient_square.dim()) if i != 0
 940                ],  # sum over the input dimension
 941            )
 942        else:
 943            gradient_square = self.next_layer(layer_name).weight.grad.data**2
 944            gradient_square_sum = torch.sum(
 945                gradient_square,
 946                dim=[
 947                    i for i in range(gradient_square.dim()) if i != 1
 948                ],  # sum over the output dimension
 949            )
 950
 951        importance_step_layer = gradient_square_sum
 952        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
 953
 954        return importance_step_layer
 955
 956    def get_importance_step_layer_weight_gradient_square_sum_x_activation_abs(
 957        self: str,
 958        layer_name: str,
 959        activation: Tensor,
 960        if_output_weight: bool,
 961    ) -> Tensor:
 962        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the sum of layer weight gradient squares multiplied by absolute values of activation. The weight gradient square is equal to fisher information in [EWC](https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.1611835114).
 963
 964        **Args:**
 965        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
 966        - **activation** (`Tensor`): the activation tensor of the layer. It has the same size of (number of units, ).
 967        - **if_output_weight** (`bool`): whether to use the output weights or input weights.
 968
 969        **Returns:**
 970        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
 971        """
 972        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
 973
 974        if not if_output_weight:
 975            gradient_square = layer.weight.grad.data**2
 976            gradient_square_sum = torch.sum(
 977                gradient_square,
 978                dim=[
 979                    i for i in range(gradient_square.dim()) if i != 0
 980                ],  # sum over the input dimension
 981            )
 982        else:
 983            gradient_square = self.next_layer(layer_name).weight.grad.data**2
 984            gradient_square_sum = torch.sum(
 985                gradient_square,
 986                dim=[
 987                    i for i in range(gradient_square.dim()) if i != 1
 988                ],  # sum over the output dimension
 989            )
 990
 991        activation_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
 992            torch.abs(activation),
 993            dim=[
 994                i for i in range(activation.dim()) if i != 1
 995            ],  # average the features over batch samples
 996        )
 997
 998        importance_step_layer = gradient_square_sum * activation_abs_batch_mean
 999        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
1000
1001        return importance_step_layer
1002
1003    def get_importance_step_layer_conductance_abs(
1004        self: str,
1005        layer_name: str,
1006        input: Tensor | tuple[Tensor, ...],
1007        baselines: None | int | float | Tensor | tuple[int | float | Tensor, ...],
1008        target: Tensor | None,
1009        batch_idx: int,
1010        num_batches: int,
1011    ) -> Tensor:
1012        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the absolute values of [conductance](https://openreview.net/forum?id=SylKoo0cKm). We implement this using [Layer Conductance](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#layer-conductance) in Captum.
1013
1014        **Args:**
1015        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
1016        - **input** (`Tensor` | `tuple[Tensor, ...]`): the input batch of the training step.
1017        - **baselines** (`None` | `int` | `float` | `Tensor` | `tuple[int | float | Tensor, ...]`): starting point from which integral is computed in this method. Please refer to the [Captum documentation](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#captum.attr.LayerConductance.attribute) for more details.
1018        - **target** (`Tensor` | `None`): the target batch of the training step.
1019        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is an argument of the forward function during training.
1020        - **num_batches** (`int`): the number of batches in the training step. This is an argument of the forward function during training.- **mask** (`Tensor`): the mask tensor of the layer. It has the same size as the feature tensor with size (number of units, ).
1021
1022        **Returns:**
1023        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
1024        """
1025        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
1026
1027        # initialize the Layer Conductance object
1028        layer_conductance = LayerConductance(forward_func=self.forward, layer=layer)
1029
1030        self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(True)
1031        # calculate layer attribution of the step
1032        attribution = layer_conductance.attribute(
1033            inputs=input,
1034            baselines=baselines,
1035            target=target,
1036            additional_forward_args=("train", batch_idx, num_batches, self.task_id),
1037        )
1038        self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(False)
1039
1040        attribution_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
1041            torch.abs(attribution),
1042            dim=[
1043                i for i in range(attribution.dim()) if i != 1
1044            ],  # average the features over batch samples
1045        )
1046
1047        importance_step_layer = attribution_abs_batch_mean
1048        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
1049
1050        return importance_step_layer
1051
1052    def get_importance_step_layer_internal_influence_abs(
1053        self: str,
1054        layer_name: str,
1055        input: Tensor | tuple[Tensor, ...],
1056        baselines: None | int | float | Tensor | tuple[int | float | Tensor, ...],
1057        target: Tensor | None,

1059        num_batches: int,
1060    ) -> Tensor:
1061        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the absolute values of [internal influence](https://openreview.net/forum?id=SJPpHzW0-). 1066        - **baselines** (`None` | `int` | `float` | `Tensor` | `tuple[int | float | Tensor, ...]`): starting point from which integral is computed in this method. Please refer to the [Captum documentation](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#captum.attr.InternalInfluence.attribute) for more details.
1067        - **target** (`Tensor` | `None`): the target batch of the training step.
1068        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is an argument of the forward function during training.

1078
1079        # convert the target to long type to avoid error

1081

1255    def get_importance_step_layer_gradientshap_abs(
1256        self: str,
1257        layer_name: str,
1258        input: Tensor | tuple[Tensor, ...],
1259        baselines: None | int | float | Tensor | tuple[int | float | Tensor, ...],
1260        target: Tensor | None,
1261        batch_idx: int,
1262        num_batches: int,
1263    ) -> Tensor:
1264        r"""Get the raw neuron-wise importance (before scaling) of a layer of a training step. See $I^{\tau}_l(\mathbf{x},y)$ (before Eqs. (5) and (6)) in the paper. This method uses the absolute values of gradient SHAP. We implement this using [Layer GradientShap](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#layer-gradientshap) in Captum.
1265
1266        **Args:**
1267        - **layer_name** (`str`): the name of layer to get neuron-wise importance.
1268        - **input** (`Tensor` | `tuple[Tensor, ...]`): the input batch of the training step.
1269        - **baselines** (`None` | `int` | `float` | `Tensor` | `tuple[int | float | Tensor, ...]`): starting point from which expectation is computed. Please refer to the [Captum documentation](https://captum.ai/api/layer.html#captum.attr.LayerGradientShap.attribute) for more details. If `None`, the baselines are set to zero.
1270        - **target** (`Tensor` | `None`): the target batch of the training step.
1271        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is an argument of the forward function during training.
1272        - **num_batches** (`int`): the number of batches in the training step. This is an argument of the forward function during training.

1274        **Returns:**
1275        - **importance_step_layer** (`Tensor`): the neuron-wise importance of the layer of the training step.
1276        """
1277        layer = self.backbone.get_layer_by_name(layer_name)
1278
1279        if baselines is None:
1280            baselines = torch.zeros_like(
1281                input
1282            )  # baselines are mandatory for GradientShap API. We explicitly set them to zero
1283
1284        # initialize the Layer GradientShap object
1285        layer_gradientshap = LayerGradientShap(forward_func=self.forward, layer=layer)

1289
1290        self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(True)
1291        # calculate layer attribution of the step
1292        attribution = layer_gradientshap.attribute(
1293            inputs=input,
1294            baselines=baselines,
1295            target=target,
1296            additional_forward_args=("train", batch_idx, num_batches, self.task_id),
1297        )
1298        self.set_forward_func_return_logits_only(False)
1299
1300        attribution_abs_batch_mean = torch.mean(
1301            torch.abs(attribution),
1302            dim=[
1303                i for i in range(attribution.dim()) if i != 1
1304            ],  # average the features over batch samples
1305        )
1306
1307        importance_step_layer = attribution_abs_batch_mean
1308        importance_step_layer = importance_step_layer.detach()
1309
1310        return importance_step_layer

1312    def get_importance_step_layer_integrated_gradients_abs(
